Award.AwardTitle: Mechanical Characterization of Atomically Thin Membranes

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Ruoff group will undertake studies of the mechanical properties of atomically thin membranes. Two tools will be used to make these measurements: An atomic force microscope will directly stress the membranes. An optical profilometer will separately be used to measure the deflection of the membranes as a function of applied pressure. Several different materials will be measured: atom-thick graphene, oxidized graphene, single layer clays, and very thin amorphous carbon films. Models will be developed to better understand the mechanical behavior of these very thin films and to extract the basic mechanical properties from the experimental data.

Such atomically thin membranes will find use in a host of important applications, such as for pressure sensing, and as electromechanical and chemical sensing elements. The database established for the mechanical response of individual layers and few-layer stacks will be relevant to understanding the role such thin platelets play in composite materials, and in a variety of applications such as nanoelectronics and senors. The project includes significant outreach such as research training for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, summer research experiences for high school and undergraduate students and high school teachers, additions to course materials used at UT Austin, and curriculum development for grades 7-12. Research results will be disseminated by publication in quality journals, and invited talks at universities, national laboratories, institutes, and other public forums, at international conferences, and on a highly visible web site.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: 800x600 Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE MicrosoftInternetExplorer4 Since the discovery of the true two-dimensional material, graphene, measurements of its mechanical properties has been challenging due to its atomic thickness. Through this project, we developed new, reliable methods to characterize the mechanical properties of ultra-thin nano-materials: (1) mechanical measurements by scanning atomic force microscopy (AFM) on membrane structures with finite element analysis and (2) force-displacement measurement by optical interferometry with pressure control on the membrane structures. Using these techniques, we characterize various ultra-thin membrane structures made of graphene grown by chemical vapor deposition (CVD), graphene oxide platelets, amorphous carbon, and nano-clay. In addition to the measurements, we developed a method to fabricate the membrane structure made of the nano-materials. For example, a thin polymer support film has been used to transfer monolayer graphene grown by CVD onto pre-fabricated substrates having through-holes of a few micrometer diameters, followed by the removal of the polymer with thermal decomposition. The YoungÆs moduli for each material have been characterized by considering the pre-stresses of the membrane structures, which improved the accuracy of the characterization methods. Particularly, we found that the chemical functionalization of graphene degraded the YoungÆs modulus due to the conversion of sp2 hybridization to sp3 hybridization. Furthermore, grain boundaries existing in large-area graphene grown by CVD decreased the YoungÆs modulus as a function of the grain boundary density in the membrane. These findings are critical for understanding the graphene-based materials as well as development of various devices made of the graphene-based materials. Furthermore, the techniques developed in this project will be very useful for characterizing other nano-matierlas. Last Modified: 09/24/2013 Submitted by: Rodney S Ruoff
